hints_html:
Multiply the matrix with the vector of x, y, z.

Once we have a particular solution, how can we write the general solution using our work from part (b)?
hints_latex: Multiply the matrix with the vector of \emph{x}, \emph{y}, \emph{z}.

Once we have a particular solution, how can we write the general
solution using our work from
{part
(b)}?
hints_raw:
Multiply the matrix with the vector of ''x'', ''y'', ''z''.
Once we have a particular solution, how can we write the general solution using our work from [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH152/April 2012/Question 2 (b)|part (b)]]?
question: 2 (c)
sols_html:
If we multiply the matrix A to the vector [1,1,1] we get

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 2 & -1 &2\\ 1 & 3 & -6\\ 3 & 2 & -4 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 3\\ -2\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and therefore a=3, b=-2, and c=1. If we set those values permanently then we know that [1,1,1] is a particular solution to the problem. However, from part(b) we have that the solution to the homogeneous problem was

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}_h=t \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 2\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and therefore we can write that the general solution \(\mathbf{x}\) is the sum of the particular and homogeneous solution,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}+t \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 2\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
If we multiply the matrix A to the vector [1,1,1] we get

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
2  &  -1  &2\\
1  &  3  &  -6\\
3  &  2  &  -4
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
3\\
-2\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

and therefore a=3, b=-2, and c=1.  If we set those values permanently then we know that [1,1,1] is a particular solution to the problem.  However, from [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH152/April 2012/Question 2 (b)|part(b)]] we have that the solution to the homogeneous problem was

:<math>
\mathbf{x}_h=t
\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
2\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

and therefore we can write that the general solution <math>\mathbf{x}</math> is the sum of the particular and homogeneous solution,

:<math>
\mathbf{x}=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}+t
\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
2\\
1
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>
statement_html:
Consider the following system of linear equations

\[\begin{aligned} 2x-y+2z&=a\\ x+3y-6z&=b\\ 3x+2y-4z&=c,\end{aligned}\]

where a,b, and c \(\in\R\).

Give that x=y=z=1 is a particular solution to the system above, determine the values of a, b, and c. Then find all the solutions in this case and express them in parametric form.
statement_latex:
Consider the following system of linear equations

\begin{align*}
2x-y+2z&=a\\
x+3y-6z&=b\\
3x+2y-4z&=c,
\end{align*}

where a,b, and c $\in\R$.

Give that x=y=z=1 is a particular solution to the system above,
determine the values of a, b, and c. Then find \emph{all} the solutions
in this case and express them in parametric form.
statement_raw:
Consider the following system of linear equations

:<math>
\begin{align}
2x-y+2z&=a\\
x+3y-6z&=b\\
3x+2y-4z&=c,
\end{align}
</math>

where a,b, and c <math>\in\R</math>.

Give that x=y=z=1 is a particular solution to the system above, determine the values of a, b, and c.  Then find ''all'' the solutions in this case and express them in parametric form.
